explained by Mr* Novik, and adequate labor leadership was involved in the
ETV movement itself, were perhaps the most significant result of the opera¬
tion of the Management Relations Service. The fine relations that have been
established in most locations between unions and ETV stations are evidence
of the excellent ground work inconspicuously laid by Mr* Novik, through
the office of President Meaney of the AFL-CIO and other national channels.
Many unions have contributed time and money to ETV. For example,
in Chicago, sizeable contributions have been made to ETV station WTTW by
the Chicago Federation of Labor. In Houston and other areas, union tech¬
nicians have helped ETV stations with their engineering problems, and in
some cases have contributed mobile units and other equipment,at no cost to
the station. In the first joint Convention of the AFL-CIO, Mr. Novik was
able to secure a special resolution of endorsement of ETV, to which American
labor pledged its national support.
Another achievement of the NAEB Management Relations Service,
second only to the above and related to it, was securing recognition of
educational television's need for special status, in rate structures for union
labor and contracts, quite different from those of commercial television.
This recognition had to be achieved promptly at the national level in time
for this national philosophy to help take the pressure off such local areas
ac. St. Louis, where local chapters of the IBEW and IATSE, particularly.
